I understand your stance that "Businesses should not be allowed to have new employees sign noncompete deals" primarily because this may limit the potential for the career growth of employees. It's indeed a valid concern--restricting competition can be seen as a delineation on personal freedom.

However, I disagree with your claim, considering the perspective of the business. Noncompete agreements are not only used as a tool of power by the employer but can serve as protection for the investment of businesses in their employees. This could mean investment in training, intellectual property or even the exposure to trade secrets. If a business invests a substantial amount of resources into an employee, it's only reasonable that they would like to protect their investment.

Still, this doesn't mean I support noncompete agreements without any limitations. The terms should be reasonable, both in duration and geographical scope, to ensure they don't excessively impede an employee's career progression.
